unnormalised: ## Virtual Classrooms: Are they the future of education in India?
normalised: ## Virtual Classrooms: Are they the future of education in India?

unnormalised: Virtual classrooms have gained significant traction in India, especially post-COVID-19. Platforms like Zoom, Google Meet, and homegrown solutions are now commonplace in institutions from IIT Delhi to smaller schools in rural Rajasthan.
normalised: Virtual classrooms have gained significant traction in India, especially post-COVID-19. Platforms like Zoom, Google Meet, and homegrown solutions are now commonplace in institutions from I I T Delhi to smaller schools in rural Rajasthan.

unnormalised: While traditionally, the chalk and talk method reigned supreme, virtual classrooms offer several advantages: accessibility to quality education regardless of geographical location (connecting students in remote areas like Arunachal Pradesh with expert teachers in Mumbai), flexibility (allowing students to learn at their own pace), and the integration of multimedia resources. Imagine a history class brought to life with virtual tours of the Taj Mahal!

unnormalised: However, challenges remain. Reliable internet connectivity, particularly in Tier-2 and Tier-3 cities, is crucial. Digital literacy among teachers and students needs further improvement. Also, the lack of face-to-face interaction can impact social development and create a sense of isolation. A lecture scheduled for 10:30 AM on 26/01/2024 might not be as effective as one conducted in person, especially if network issues arise.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the cost of devices and data can be a barrier for some families. Addressing these challenges is paramount to ensuring equitable access to virtual education. My cousin, Priya, who teaches at a government school in Patna, faced exactly this situation on 15/08/2023 during a special independence day program.
